name: 81 Cuts drill
description:
Cut 1 –Diagonal top right to bottom left
Cut 2 – Diagonal top left to bottom right
Cut 3 – Horizontal right to left
Cut 4 – Horizontal left to right
Cut 5 – Straight stab/thrust lower abdomen
Cut 6 – Diagonal bottom left to top right
Cut 7 – Diagonal bottom right to top left
Cut 8 – Straight stab/thrust to upper left clavicle cavity
Cut 9 – Straight stab/thrust to upper right clavicle cavity
STUDENTS MUST DRILL THE 81 CUTS AT THIS POINT

name: Stop by following means
description:
Structurally – Bones and Joints
Mechanically – Muscles and Tendons
Pneumatically – Air passages
Hydraulically – Loss of fluids
Electrically – Disruption of the nervous system
Chemically – Mixing of body fluids, toxicity
Make sure you break your opponents OODA cycle (Observation, Orientation, Decision and Action) to gain an advantage

name: Parries
description: Parry any knife attack using a slapping motion to the opponent’s forearm. Same side refers to same side as your parrying hand, cross side refers to opposite side to your parrying hand.

description: Palm heel high line strike same side straight up (1&2)

12 count strikes
description:
Left and right are opponent’s side:
1. Left head/neck
2. Right head/neck
3. Left ribs
4. Right ribs
5. Left abdomen
6. Right abdomen
7. Left Knee
8. Right Knee
9. Left Collarbone/chest
10. Right Collarbone/chest
11. Left diagonal down head
12. Right Diagonal down head

name: 12 count blocks
description:
When blocking with one stick make sure hand is behind stick.
Blocks are repetitive 1, 3 and 2, 4 are the same, Block stick with stick and hand with hand
5&6 Block stick downwards hand on hand
7&8 Block stick downwards hand on hand, Palm up
11 Block stick, overhead touching shoulder

name: Hitting the hand
description: That is holding the stick, then take stick with other hand. Here you may use wittick and normal strikes. Same movements as on the blocking drill.

name: Snake disarm
description: Here you use your arm (doesn’t matter which one) to curl around your opponents weapon and with a quick movement disarm him/her.

name: Grapevine
description: Use you stick as leverage to get the other stick out of your opponents arm.

name: Stripping
description: Glide along the opponents stick with yours, hitting the hand and pulling away the stick

name: Modified
description: High, forehand and back hand, low forehand and backhand

name: Broken
description: High, forehand, low forehand, low backhand, high back hand

Deflection from decapitation
description: Must be accompanied by counter attack

description: Must be accompanied by counter attack

name: Deflection from low-level cut
description: Must be accompanied by counter attack

name: Deflection from stright thrust high/ low
description: Must be accompanied by counter attack

name: 9 Cut Kata
description:
1. Unsheathe, step forward jab to throat
2. Lower blade, jab between ribs
3. Step Forward into J-Cut
4. Change Grip, step forward into upward diagonal cut
5. Decapitate
6. Step backwards, while slashing one handed diagonally downward
7. Change grip, Diagonal cut upward
8. Decapitate
9. Downward vertical cut while thrusting forward (KIA)
10. Blood Let
11. Re-sheath
12. Step Back while Bowing at the same time

name: Etiquette Kata
description:
1. Unsheathe and present weapon (Cutting edge facing you)
2. Down onto right knee
3. Left Knee Down
4. Blade to ground
5. Right hand to knee
6. Left hand to knee
7. Left Hand Zai
8. Right hand Zai
9. Bow
10. Right hand knee
11. Left hand knee
12. Left hand blade
13. Right hand grip
14. Lift, present, re-sheath, right hand to knee
15. Draw and Decapitate, lifting right knee off the ground (KIA)
16. Thrust left foot forward and cut opponent in half vertically (KIA)
17. Blood Let
18. Re-sheath
19. Step back and bow

name: Ninja - Archery History
description:
The bow was known as a “Yumi” and the arrows were called, “Ya”. The ninja’s bow was short and symmetrical, with a center grip, similar to the larger ones we’ll be training with today. Whereas the longer, asymmetrical Yumi were favored by the Samurai, with the grip lower down on the bow.  The ninja’s shorter bow meant less range on the battlefield, but allowed for closer and more accurate kills with agility.
Ninjas were proficient in using both types of bows, and when needed, could also use the bows from fallen samurai on the battlefield.
Female ninja were called “Kunoichi”, and were often experts with the bow and arrow.
When removing the string from the bow, called “slacking”, a ninja could hide the bow with some arrows in a hollow bamboo tube.  This was a great for carrying them over their back, freeing up their hands, or even useful in disguising the assassins as a contractor, who used to carry their blue prints inside bamboo tubes.
There were many types of arrows used for different occasions, whether it be a standard arrow head or an explosive one.  Wooden arrows could be dipped in poison to insure any wound was a fatal one.  The Togari-Ya was a simple pointed arrow head design, and a Yanagi-Ba, also known as the “Willow-Leaf” was of a more elegant design.  Rope-cutters were called “Karimata” and had a unique split point. The barbed “Watakushi” was used for tearing flesh. And the Tagone-Ya was shaped like a chisel.
For creating a loud whistling effect, the “Kaburi-Ya” was used to strike fear into the hearts of the enemy, or for signalling allies.  These arrows where large enough that they could be signed on, or relay short messages.
And for a more silent approach, certain reeds used with the making of an arrow, could dampen the sound it would make from flying through the air.
Some say that bamboo arrows were favored among ninjas as they were small and light, making them easy to carry, but still very effective.
